results.title: A Survey of acrylic techniques
results.brief_description: Acrylic paints and mediums are the most versatile and permanent materials available to artists today. The range of techniques is astounding. In this tape artist Russell Woody will show you the basics in creating oil-like tactile heavy painting, acrylic watercolours, marbling applications, collage and decoupage, through textile to sculpture. He will also detail all the basic rules for the use of supports, grounds and the use of the varied acrylic mediums. This tape is a practical, fast paced, easy to understand guide to all that acrylics can do.

results.title: A Sunday in the Country = Un Dimanche a la Campagne
results.creator_credit: Bertrand Tavernier, Alain Sarde, Little Bear, Films A2 and Sara Films
results.brief_description: A poignant and gently paced portrayal of one day in the life of M. Ladmiral, a French painter nearing the end of his life. As is usual on Sundays, M. Ladmiral is visited at his country home by his children from the city - the devoted Edouard with his petit bourgeois wife and three children and the lively Irene, M. Ladmiral’s beautiful daughter. This Sunday, as the day unfolds, a telling family portrait is gradually revealed with the sensitivity that only Tavernier can bring to the screen.

results.title: A Summer's tale = Conte d'ete
results.creator_credit: Eric Rohmer, Margaret Menegoz, Canal+, Sofilmka, La Sept Cinema and Les Films du Losange
results.brief_description:
Episode number 3 of Series “Tales of the four seasons = Contes des quatre saisons”.
Gaspard (Melvil Poupard), a musically inclined maths graduate with time to kill is waiting for his girlfriend, Lena, in the resort town of Dinard, unbeknownst that his stable and uneventful life is about to be turned on it head when he becomes torn between his affections for three women. He whiles away the lazy afternoon hours with Margot (Amanda Langlet), a part time student and pancake house worker, and most importantly - a good listener. Margot wants a purely platonic relationship with Gaspard as she already has a boyfriend. Enter likely candidate number three, Margot’s friend Solene (Gwenaelle Simon), whom Gaspard becomes instantly smitten with and agrees to spend a weekend with on the island of Ouessant. When Lena finally arrives on the island Gaspard must finally make a choice between three women who are all offering him something different in the relationship stakes. In French with English subtitles. This film, the third in Rohmer’s “4 Season cycle” finds the director in fine story telling form.

results.title: A Sugar-cane farm in Fiji
results.creator_credit: Concept Films of Australia and Pilgrim Films
results.brief_description: Presents a case study of a sugar cane farm in Fiji as an example of cane farming. The yearly agricultural program and mill processes are covered. Also considers the importance of sugar cane to the Fijian economy.

results.title: A Sufi tale
results.creator_credit: Gayle Thomas and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This animated film is based on an old Persian parable. The inhabitants of a village learn to overcome their fear of the unknown. The benefit of their new-found knowledge is demonstrated. The black-and-white images are reminiscent of German wood-cuts. No dialogue. Music by Normand Roger performed by Gropus 7. (Awards: Athens, USA; Espinho; Murcia.)

results.title: A Study of crystals using microscopic fusion methods
results.creator_credit: Gilbert Altschul Productions and Journal Films
results.brief_description: Depicts fusion methods in chemical research using live-action laboratory sequences, animation and microphotography; also shows patterns of crystal growth under the microscope.

results.title: A Study in wet
results.brief_description: There is no narration in this study of the many forms of water. A bright-colored surfboard is reflected in rippling water and the image returns as a kind of punctuation mark throughout the film. The abstract patterns of water and spray introduce other uses of water and the film ends in a climactic surfing sequence with experts riding giant waves.

results.title: A Study in choreography for camera
results.brief_description: This is the third film of the prominent American experimental film-maker, Maya Deren. It elaborates a technique developed in her previous film ‘At Land’ in which fresh contiguities of shot relations were achieved through the device of photographing a movement begun in one place, and concluding it by photographing the completion of the movement in another place, thus creating a cinematic time and place which enabled unrelated persons, place and objects to be related and brought into harmony, resulting in a new complexity of meaning and form. ‘A Study in Choreography for Camera’ features a leap by the dancer Talley Beatty, in which he begins his leap in the woods, continues it against the background of the Metropolitan Museum’s Egyptian Hall, and finishes it on the cliffs overlooking a river. Slow motion is used to prolong and dramatise the movement. John Martin, dance critic of the ‘New York Times’ called this film “virtually the beginnings of a new art, choreocinema, in which the dancer and the camera collaborate on the creation of a single new work of art.”

results.title: A Streetcar named Desire
results.creator_credit: Elia Kazan and Charles K. Feldman
results.brief_description: Blanche Dubois, a faded Southern belle whose fortunes have crumbled to nothing, comes to New Orleans to stay with her sister, Stella. Stella’s husband, the brutish but magnetic Stanley Kowalski is suspicious of her past and puts in train a devastating chain of events which will finally destroy for all time Blanche’s already tenuous grasp on the world of reality. Stars Vivien Leigh and Marlon Brando. Based on the play by Tennessee Williams. Also stars Karl Malden.

results.title: A Streetcar named desire
results.creator_credit: John Erman, Marc Trabulus and Keith Barish Productions
results.brief_description: Blanche Dubois, a faded Southern belle whose fortunes have crumbled to nothing, comes to New Orleans to stay with her sister, Stella. Stella’s husband, the brutish but magnetic Stanley Kowalski is suspicious of her past and puts in train a devastating chain of events which will finally destroy for all time Blanche’s already tenuous grasp on the world of reality. Directed by John Erman for television, this version of “A Streetcar called desire” cannot help but invite comparisons to the 1954 Vivien Leigh/Marlon Brando version directed by Elia Kazan, which is the most famous adaptation of Tennessee Williams’ play. Nonetheless the three leads - Ann-Margaret, Treat Williams, Beverly D’Angelo - make a fine job of the material in a more realistic presentation of the play which goes to great lengths to establish the physical and moral decay of New Orleans in the 1940s. Also featuring Randy Quaid.
